Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Connections between the Nonlinear Spectroscopy and the Potential Energy Landscapes of Liquids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Richard M. Stratt of Brown University is supported by the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division for his research on the relationships between the unusually slow molecular dynamicsseen in liquid mixtures, liquid crystals, and supercooled liquids, and the global features of the potential-energy landscapes of these systems. While slow dynamics is often understandable as a consequence of the need to rearrange individual chemical bonds or surmount other local bottlenecks on the potential energy surface, in many of the most interesting cases, the issue is more the difficulty in locating and traversing even the most efficient global pathways through the landscape. This work investigates how computer simulations can be used to characterize these most efficient ("geodesic") pathways and attempts to forge quantitative connections between the information garnered from these pathways and that available from novel nonlinear spectroscopies. The spectroscopic half of the research is focused on solute pump/solvent-probe spectra, in particular, because those spectra have the potential to reveal how broad swaths of solvent structure can rearrange in the presence of a newly electronically excited solute. By computing the spectra expected from preferentially solvating mixtures, dye-doped liquid crystals, and fragile-glass-forming liquids, and comparing the outcomes with the results of a geodesic landscape analysis, the researchers hope to learn how spectroscopy can be used to discover what is so unique about the potential energy landscapes of these especially slow systems.

Professor Stratt and his research group are developing computational methods to explore the relationship between the slow molecular dynamics seen in liquids mixtures, liquid crystals and supercooled liquids and certain features of the potential energy landscapes of these systems. A potential energy landscape is the interaction energy of the atoms in the system as a function of the distances between the atoms. Stratt's research focuses on how to find the most efficient pathways through these landscapes; such pathways determine the actual motions of the atoms. Stratt also develops theoretical methods to predict and analyze spectra that help us to understand how solvents react to molecules that are in an excited electronic state. The eventual payoff for this research may be useful insight into two enormously important practical problems involving slow molecular rearrangements: determining the properties of glassy and amorphous materials, and understanding how and when proteins fold incorrectly. The toughness and ease of processing of amorphous substances often makes them ideal commercial materials, but there is surprisingly little consensus about many of the scientific fundamentals of glassiness. Similarly, proteins that resist folding into well-ordered structures are essential to living organisms, but some of those that fold in an amorphous fashion are markers of critical human health problems, including Alzheimer's disease. The research involves undergraduates as research coworkers, thereby enriching their scientific education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is hardly a surprise that the progress of science closely follows the discoveries of new technologies for probing ever deeper into how nature works.  But in large measure, that progress is just as dependent on advent of new theoretical technologies: new ways of formulating scientific puzzles, new ways of analyzing experimental findings, and new ways of calculating the often surprising implications of seemingly simple conceptual insights.  The motion of molecules in liquids, the subject of this project, makes for an interesting case in point.

            In trying to understand the puzzles posed by the examples we focused on in this project – how liquid solvents reorganize to enable chemical reactions to occur (“solvation”), how substances capable of acting as though they were part liquid and part solid (“liquid crystals”) behave, and how some liquids can be seemingly unable to figure out how to freeze (“supercooled liquids”) – we faced a difficult task.  The essential randomness of molecular motions in liquids makes it difficult to tease out whatever patterns the molecules may trace out.  The key realization we had, though, was that the issue is not the plethora of apparently random molecular arrangements, but the relatively limited list of accessible pathways that the molecules have to follow to reach those arrangements.  It is as if molecules were perennially hiking over a forbidding landscape filled with all manners of mountains, valleys, and swamps, but one could always predict the highlights of their travels by surveying a few selected trails before the molecules even left camp.

            What our research group figured out how to do was how to use computer simulation to locate and characterize these molecular trails for a number of central problems in liquid-state dynamics.  Using these techniques, we found that it was the increasingly long paths that these crucial trails required that explained why certain supercooled liquids move so slowly.  The same kinds of calculations revealed why liquid-crystal-forming molecules translate much more easily than they rotate under certain conditions.  Since that pattern is also a hallmark of supercooled liquids, this finding seemed to indicate an unexpected parallel between two seemingly distinct instances of liquid motion.  Further, at the same time we were pursuing this pathway analysis, we found that there could be potential experimental signatures of characteristic liquid pathways during solvation.  Our theoretical studies of  “two-dimensional solvation spectroscopy” pointed out that paths that led to significant molecular rearrangements could be distinguished from more prosaic paths that left the liquid structure largely inviolate.

            It is worth emphasizing that much of this work was carried out in collaboration with both graduate and undergraduate students.  Undergraduates are frequently thought of as lacking the necessary skills or background to participate in mathematically and scientifically sophisticated theoretical research.  However, as part of the “broader impact” considerations of our work, we thought that this project could serve to demonstrate how such research could be made accessible to undergraduate students in a way that would be educationally valuable to them while still contributing to the scientific progress on a forefront project.  The fact that three of the published journal articles that arose from this project had undergraduates as first authors points out both the viability and promise of this way of ensuring broader exposure to scientific research endeavors.
